result.rationale: The species is endemic to Lake Matano in Sulawesi, where it is only found in rocky substrate areas with an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 141 km2 and an area of occupancy (AOO) of 60 km2. This is counted as one location based on the threats of nickel mining, hydro-electric power installations, logging, and organic effluents from the rapidly expanding human population, which are causing a decline in habitat quality through siltation and changes to natural water levels. Most critically, this species is thought to have suffered a population decline of at least 50% in the last 10 years due predation of small adults and juveniles by invasive Flowerhorn Cichlids (Colossoma sp.), because few or no individuals were observed in areas it was common in 2002-2003 (T. von Rintelen pers. obs. 2017, 2018). An overall population decline of at least 50% is also predicted over the next 10 years due to the continued impact of Flowerhorn Cichlids in Lake Matano (T. von Rintelen pers. comm. 2018). Due to the suspected past decline, predicted future decline, its limited distribution and persistent threats, this species is assessed as Endangered.
result.geographicrange: The species is endemic to Lake Matano (164.1 km2), which is part of the Malili Lakes system in Sulawesi, Indonesia.
result.population: This species has previously been reported as abundant (von Rintelen et al. 2007), but during a recent visit (2017) to two sites in Lake Matano where it was common in 2002-2003 fewer or no individuals, respectively, were observed. This is thought to be due to invasive Flowerhorn Cichlids (Colossoma sp.) introduced to Lake Matano, which spread throughout the entire lake in under 10 years (Herder et al. 2012) and likely predated small adults and juveniles of this species (T. von Rintelen pers. comm. 2018). There is therefore thought to have been a population decline of >50% over the last 10 years. An overall population decline of at least 50% is also predicted over the next 10 years due to the continued impact of Flowerhorn Cichlids in Lake Matano (T. von Rintelen pers. comm. 2018).
result.habitat: This species occurs in the freshwater Lake Matano and is a hard substrate dweller on rocks and wood.
result.threats:
Current threats to the species are nickel mining and hydro-electric power installations on the outlet of Danau Matano, which impact the outflow and natural water level fluctuations throughout the entire lake system. Siltation due to erosion and organic effluents from the rapidly expanding human population around the lakes are also problematic.

Many species of Tylomelania are being collected for the aquarium pet trade. Tylomelania matannensis does not seem to be traded yet, though, and is unlikely to become a major target.

Finally, invasive species (particularly Flowerhorn cichlids, Colossoma sp.) have been introduced to Lake Matano and have unknown but potentially serious consequences through predation of small adults and juveniles (Herder et al. 2012), as in 2017 few or no individuals were observed in areas where this species was common in 2002-2003 (T. von Rintelen pers. obs. 2017).
result.conservationmeasures: No conservation plans are currently in place for this species, but protection of its known localities and habitats is needed alongside invasive species control. Research is also needed into the population dynamics, ecology and the threats to this species.
result.usetrade: There is no use or trade information available for this species. Many species of Tylomelania of the Malili lakes are collected and traded as aquarium pets, however this species has not yet been conspicuously traded.
